author: Nicolas Silva

text:
@Nicolas Silva, thanks for stopping by! 

not sure, not getting an error in it; I have 4 very-slightly different analyses that I apply iteratively on small subsets of a large dataset, used to be a for loop.

The used-to-be for loop would initialize an analysis 4 times with slightly different input, to store output in 4 different 2-d arrays.

Instead of a for loop I now use `pool.starmap(func_analyze_a_subset, two_argument_arrays_zipped)` method inside a `with multiprocessing.Pool(16) as pool:`-block, followed by a `pool.close()` and `pool.join()`; 4 times, one time for each similarly-slightly-different-argument variation.

It seems that the first with block runs according to plan, and then it all halts without any error message to %tb, and sometimes the entire kernel resets at halting; this is performed on a JupyterLab Notebook, running python 3.6 on science platform with 16 cores and 240 GB RAM.

`func_analyze_subset` itself utilizes 3 global numpy arrays (~12 MB in memory, each), as well as a global dictionary containing 64 arrays (~1 GB, each). 

None of the arrays are re-written or modified, only read from by array slicing, so as to retrieve the aforementioned subsets - as far as I understand, no deep-copying is performed. Thus I believed that python would manage not to kill itself from memory overload, and as far as I can see from `top` in bash, memory is not flooded, but I can be misinterpreting what I see - and the most likely explanation, I think, is that I don't manage the memory properly.

Every example I can find with memory management uses the `Process` functionality instead, and from the examples andxproblems of others that I can find on the web, Process would in my case not be ideal to use: subset analysis function will be called upon approximately 1.5 million times.

Of course, I could restructure somehow, for example I already thought about getting rid of the second input argument by getting doing each of the 4 analyses after one another, inside the analysis function. Its output could simply be reshaped, so that would work; but that still wouldn't get around my problem, if the problem is memory.

Thanks for reading by!﻿

text:
""" Practice"""
"""Body mass Index is the result of dividing the weight(kg) by the square of the height in meters """
""" Find the Body Mass Index (BMI) using the metric system in this example"""
""" BMI is Indication of Obesity"""

""" Ask for the Name of the User """
name = input("Please Enter your Name:   ")
Weight = int(input("Please Enter Your Weight(Kg):   "))
Height = int(input("Please Enter Your Height (M):   "))
BMI = Weight//((Height/100)**2)
if BMI < 18.5:
    print(f'"Ms/Mr {name} Your BMI equals: {BMI}"')
    print("You are Underweight ,,, Please Check with your Physician")
elif 18.5 <= BMI <= 25:
    print(f'"Ms/Mr {name} Your BMI is equal to:  {BMI}')
    print("This is a Normal value ,,, Keep the Good Work")
elif 25 < BMI < 30:
    print(f"Ms/Mr {name} Your BMI is equal to: {BMI}")
    print("You are overweight ,, better check with your Physician")
elif 30 < BMI <= 34.9:
    print(f"Ms/Mr {name} Your BMI is equal to:  {BMI}")
    print("You Are in Obesity Stage I,,, you Better refer to Your Physician")
elif 35 < BMI <= 39.9:
    print(f"Ms/Mr {name} Your BMI is equal to:  {BMI}")
    print("You Are in Obesity Stage II,,, you Better refer to Your Physician")
else:
    print(f"Your BMI is equal to:  {BMI}")
    print("You Are in Obesity Stage III,,, you are at Real Risk Must refer to Your Physician")﻿

text:
Not really an exact answer to your question, but relevant. 

If many times to get into programming. There were parts of if that made sense, but I still had some fundamental issues grasping certain things. Your video has been absolutely amazing. I can't really explain why it helps more than others or what about it helped me as opposed to other 'learn to code' video lessons I've tried. I'm specifically interested in python for doing raspberry pi projects. I'm already fairly technical, but my specialty is hardware. Software, and more specifically programing, has always been my downfall. In addition to python, I'm also very interested in shell scripting and have been trying to learn that as well, mainly to automate things on my unraid server. 

Your lesson has been so helpful and I've never felt as confident as I do while learning from you. Thanks so much for putting this together!
PS. Do you mind if I archive your video for offline viewing?
also, liked and subbed.﻿

author: Joe Dalton

text: At 3:54:00 :  Windows users attempting to install the openpyxl package from the terminal may need to change the directory to their user directory first.  Do this by entering  cd c:\Users\UserName in the command line.  In order to install the openpyxl package, you may also need to use a different command than what is shown in the video as well.  This command will be py pip -m install openpyxl OR python pip -m install openpyxl depending on how you chose to install the Python interpreter.  Mosh is using a Mac which has a Unix based OS so Windows commands are a bit different.  Hope this helps.  Cheers!﻿

text:
Tip for those using actual excel for "Project 1: Automation with Python": you have to use capital letter for the cell reference, like this: sheet.add_chart(chart, "E2"). 
In Mosh's code it shows with lower case e: (sheet.add_chart(chart, "e2"), but this caused a bunch of errors for me. changing it to capital letter, solved it all﻿

author: Kai Jin

text: You asked what “we” want to do with Python.  It is pretty simple.  We are a company that has a development language that is not open source (it is proprietary).  The licensing is nuts for the clients.  We have around 24,000 source programs that need to be rewritten.  We wrote a few of the modules in PHP and I was not impressed with PHP.   Our system is extremely I/O intensive and that does not seem to be in PHP’s wheelhouse.  Python seems, at this point, to be able to handle that well. However, I like loading database tables into memory using, as much as possible, 3 dimensional arrays.  This style significantly reduces disk I/O however the trade off is actual memory.  So, my goal is to rewrite the significant pieces in Python.    Great videos by the way.  Thank you for having them.  FYI we are a Linux shop and prior to that we were an SCO Unix shop.﻿

text:
What i understood from your question was that you want to print those variable's values after taking inputs from user.
Here's how we do it------
print("hye {} You are {} years old and your favourite color is {}.".format(name,age,color))

author: Tuấn Phạm

text: I signed up for the course after watching this video and honestly, i found the paid content very disappointing after completing the free YouTube video. The explanation's are so shallow, there's no activities to make you think for yourself (it's just repeat after me, minimal retention stuff) and there's many discrepancies between Mac/windows/linux users that Mosh either doesn't pick up on or can't be bothered to mention. There's also no troubleshooting or comments section like on this YouTube video to help with specific problems you will come across or discussion board for people having the same issue. Sure you can google it but it would be nice to have a common problems section on each lesson, with such a new subject it's hard to even know what to google and i found several times i'd spend hours trying to fix what turned out to be a simple enough problem. I think Mosh needs to go back over his paid content, fix discrepancies and include some support section rather than churning out more inferior quality paid content. My advice after you've completed this excellent course is to look elsewhere for your next learning steps.﻿

author: Munir Abdulkabir

text:
age_of = input('enter ur age' )
birth_year = 2019 - int(age_of)
print('your birth year is ' + str(birth_year))

do it like this, because in the "birth_year = 2019 - int(age_of)" you change the age_of to integer data type so that it will proceed with normal mathematical procedure.

then there is a rule that you cannot concatenate String with Integer so use "str()" parameter to convert int to str.﻿

author: my Chanel

text:
For those who encounter operational error with no such table: main.auth_user__old when try to add a orange product
1. upgrade django to 2.1.5 by pip install django==2.1.5
2. delete migrates file except __init__.py
3. delete db.sqlite3
4. run "python3 manage.py makemigrations"
5. run "python3 manage.py migrate"
BTW, there is other reason operational error will emerge, and this is the way I solve it.﻿

import math #Why do we need this?

def get_values_return_ave(all_values):
    print("Type in values one-by-one, press enter to finish.")
    theSum,i=0,0
    val=input("Enter value #"+str(i)+': ')
    while val!='': #this is a sentinal loop to get the values
        i+=1
        val=eval(val)
        theSum+=val
        all_values.append(val)
        val=input("Enter value #"+str(i)+': ')
    if i>0: return theSum/i  
    return None
    
def std_deviation(values,ave): 
    """Function returns the standard deviation of a list of numbers"""
    std_dev=0
    the_sum=0
    for val in values:
        the_sum=the_sum+(ave-val)**2
    n=len(values) #number of items in values list
    std_dev=math.sqrt(the_sum/(n-1))
    return std_dev #this function does nothing useful, yet.

def median(values):
    """Function returns the median of a list of numbers"""
    values.sort()
    n=len(values)
    middle=n//2
    if n%2==1:
        return values[middle] 
    else:
        return (values[middle-1] + values[middle])/2
     
    
if __name__=="__main__":  #conditional execution
    the_values=[]
    ave=get_values_return_ave(the_values)    #FIRST: find errors in average
 
    if ave!=None:
        s=std_deviation(the_values,ave) #SECOND: get Standard Deviation to work
        med=median(the_values)   #THIRD: get median to work.
        
        outputStr="{0:<10s}= {1:<3.2f}"#format string, 's'-string,'f'-floating point
        
        print("-"*10)
        print("\nStatistics\n----------")
        print(outputStr.format("\tAverage",ave)) 
        print(outputStr.format("\tStd. Dev.",s)) 
        print(outputStr.format("\tMedian",med)) 
        print("-"*10)

text: @Etimbuk Udoudo I am still new to it myself.....but it's like a cake recipe. If you take the right "ingredients".....& put them together.....you can make anything! Learning Python....PHP.... JavaScript...HTML...and maybe Django?....you'll have the tools to do it all!....as for the "hacking" side of things? I would say, build your own little "network" at home....get creative with virtual machines....use multiple Operating Systems....(with Linux as your base...mainly ones like Kali Linux or Parrot OS)....then? when you've got everything setup and secured? Try to break in!.....try to alter files....transfer ownership of files and directories.....remove/alter table settings etc. To me?.....that is the beginning of a "hacker's" career. Just make sure to be a "White Hat" and not a "Black Hat" hacker! You might make more as a black hat? But you'll never be safe from the "agencies" (both foreign AND domestic!) that will come after you! 😂😆🤣﻿

author: Etimbuk Udoudo

text:
@Etimbuk Udoudo  The only way you'll learn the computer?......and all it's capable of? Is to start with the basics. Here's what you do:
Get yourself a laptop (for portability) I'd personally go with a Lenovo ThinkPad T-420/T-430/T -450.... they're easy to own.....inexpensive since they're a bit older than current models....and TOTALLY UPGRADABLE! you can increase the hard drive to a 1TB SSD....you can max out the RAM to 16GB. And that's pretty much it. Start there.....get a USB stick (at least 8GB) go to:
https://www.DistroWatch.com and take a look at all the variations or "flavors" of GNU/Linux....and BSD that's listed there. Before you do ANYTHING ELSE?.....

Read. 

Read up on everything you can for the distro (shorthand for "distribution") that you're interested in. Seeing as how you're totally new? I'd say try Linux Mint....or Xubuntu two distros that you should feel comfortable with if you've ever used a computer. Then as you use 'em?....and get more familiar with the Linux-sphere? Branch out and try others. That's your fist set of goals for the year 2019!....

Good Luck!﻿

author: Sufyan Sher

text: Hi Mosh, thanks for the awesome tutorial! 😃 I'm 3hrs30 in and I'm really enjoying your friendly teaching style and your patient explanations, gradually building on previous lessons, which combine to make each new concept so much easier to understand! In that spirit, I'd like to share something I just discovered with anyone else who might be interested. At 3:29:00, at the end of "Modules", you explain how to use the Python built-in "max" function to "print(max(numbers))". So I tried the same thing with the "find_max" function you created in your end-of-lesson exercise and I was pleased to find that the same single line of code "print(find_max(numbers))" also returns the highest number in the list, without the need to define the variable "maximum" in the previous line of code (allowing that line to be deleted). 👍 Anyway, thanks again for the great tutorial, I'm looking forward to the next 2hrs45! 😃﻿

text:
Hello Mosh, you are a very well spoken and fluent teacher. I appreciate your hard work and effort!
Looking for some advice from anyone who may be able to help:
Which (if any) specialization would you say has a lower barrier for entry for someone with no prior history? 
I have a creative mind, I can be very analytical and detail oriented, but I like exercising my creativity for problem-solving. I would like to perhaps be involved in or create something, which would add value to people's lives or make something easier for them. I'm not sure what this is yet since it hasn't been invented. I would like to invent it or be a part of a team that invents it. I'm not sure which direction to go in order to achieve that goal. I suppose "beggars can't be choosers" applies, so I'd be happy with any job in the programming fields. I'm doing theodinproject but that is for full-stack web development. I'm not sure if I should skip web dev and go straight to Python for AI or something else other than web dev specifically... 
Any advice if possible? I understand you're busy and can't respond to everyone. Thank you in any case. Maybe someone else can help also :)﻿

text:
At 2:13:00 -  The Duplicates are not really "removed" from the original list. Rather the uniques are just shifted to another list. I know that sounds silly, but if you really want to remove them then i used the following way.


list = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 5, 3, 1]

for item in list:
    if list.count(item) > 1:
        list.remove(item)
list.sort()
print(list)﻿

Mosh - great lesson. Coming to programming after several years and your approach to teaching is truly refreshing. list = [4, 67, 32, 45, 12, 45, 77, 32]
for index in list:
    count_num = list.count(index)
    if count_num > 1:
        list.remove(index)
print(list)

Thoughts?﻿

author: Kartik Ostwal

text:
I take a stab at it for you... 
Line 1: he initially sets the value of x to 10 by using x = 10
Forcing the value of ten into x i.e                                x <- 10
Line 2: he then wants to add an additional 3 to the value of x (which is currently set at 10) so he uses an "absolute" reference by completely resetting  the value of x by saying x = x + 3 or you might think of it as x = 10 + 3, which as you know then sets x to 13.
 Line 3 he is using a slightly different method to write the same thing as line 2. Instead of using an "absolute" value where he is resetting everything, he is using something that could be considered more like an "incremental" gain.
This is where it get ever so slightly more complicated... using x +=3 could be thought of as saying retain the value of x (which is currently 10) and add 3 to it.
The "+=" is seen by the compiler to mean = (equal) your current x value + add an extra 3. 
Some programming languages don't care if you write it as += or =+ it means the same thing. Equal what you already are, and add an extra + 3﻿
author: Dodgy Brothers Engineering

text:

reallyReallyLongIntegerVariableName = reallyReallyLongIntegerVariableName + 3
vs
reallyReallyLongIntegerVariableName =+ 3﻿

text: I learned BASIC for the Apple IIc in high school and taught myself BASIC for the Commodore 64, 128 and Amiga.  I've also taught myself some HTML.  My background is in biology and social studies, so computers and I don't always get along.  I know practically nothing about hardware.  So I'm many steps lower than even an absolute beginner when it comes to modern programming languages.  It never fails that whenever the book or video you have was made the information in it for installing what you need to install to use a given language is out of date.  So, when a book or video tells the user to go to a website and download something to get started, some effort should be made to explain what specific files are needed.  When I went to python.org it was mere chance that I managed to download what I need for my particular computer and operating system.﻿

text:
The reason that it doesn't work is because once i gets to 25, then when you divide it by two, it becomes 12.5, and so it never reaches a length of 1 for the if statement to become true.
You could either fix it by having the if statement condition be something else, like if i < 10, or you could specifically ask that, when dividing, it returns an integer instead of a float by doing something like this:
i = int(i / 2)
This means that it will only stick to whole numbers, so when you measure the length, it will stop once it is a single-digit number﻿

I looked around for an answer, and the best one I found was this one:
https://www.jetbrains.com/help/pycharm/creating-and-running-your-first-django-project.html


It implies that you need to be running PyCharm Professional Edition in order for Django to be supported. So, I got PyCharm Professional and followed the tutorial on the link above. After that, I tried to do the PyShop tutorial again, but this time I set up the project as a Django project as described in the link above. This time I was able to complete the PyShop tutorial without any problems.﻿

author: Lee Plays

text: The only reason I want to learn pytnon is because it is a very very great start for beginners. It's easy and straight forward. Much much less complicated than JavaScript that all these tuturials and developers keep recommending for us beginners. I've been working on JavaScript for the last two years and man it's freaking hard. I've gotten better at it, but I still see that python is the way to go for me. Again, very straight forward. This is one side. The other side is that I was born and raised in a very broken country. We didn't enjoy any of the technologies that are available in this world. I lived in a city of 55 thousand people and only one person in that whole city had a computer. He was a friend of mine. Every time I went to his house I'd sigh a lot wishing that I had the same. I have loved computers the second I saw them. I wanted to learn how to speak to them in their own languages. I can sit in front of my laptop for hours and never get bored nor tired of it. I just enjoy programming so much that I'd start shaking when I think about the future developer I will become. The best thing to isolate myself from our world's problems is to code. Thank you for your amazing tutorial(s). I've learned a lot from you. You and other good developers like you here on YouTube are making my dream come true. Thank you, again. :)﻿

author: annya singh

text: Are  you having trouble installing the openpyxl? If so, execute the command "pip install openpyxl"  in the command prompt on your windows. Search for the directory where Python is installed in your machine and navigate to that path on the cmd prompt and try to run the command and it will work. For instance, i had to enter cd C:\Users\<Username>\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python37\Scripts in my machine and executed the pip, it worked.﻿

text:
Rock Paper Scissor game in python all because of this great tutorial:


import random

rule = print("""
rock = 1
paper = 2
scissor = 3
""")
number = int(input("enter any no btw 1 - 3: "))
rock = 1
paper = 2
scissor = 3
computer = random.randrange(1, 4)
if number == 1:
    if computer == 3:
        print('rock : '" scissor")
        print("you win")
    elif computer == 2:
        print('rock : '" paper")
        print("computer win")
    else:
        print('rock : '" rock")
        print("match clash")
elif number == 2:
    if computer == 1:
        print('paper :'" rock")
        print("you win")
    elif computer == 3:
        print('paper :'" scissor")
        print("computer win")
    else:
        print('paper : '" paper")
        print("match clash")
elif number == 3:
    if computer == 2:
        print('scissor :'" paper")
        print("you win")
    elif computer == 1:
        print('scissor :'" rock")
        print("computer win")
    else:
        print('scissor : '" scissor")
        print("match clash")
else:
    print("i didn't get you, try one more time")﻿

1-Be for beginner junior developer. Simulate SDLC with Docker.
2-Docker with production and test environments.
3-Developments on their own computer (development environment or test environment) then transfer to the prod environment.
4-Transfering the project from the prod environment to the test environment (may be micro services)
5-Separate docker containers (separate for the database, separate for web server, separate for micro servicers ...) or all of them in a Container to be told more useful?﻿

    print(f'You weigh {wt} kilograms!')
elif unit == 'K' or 'k':
    wt /= 0.45
    print(f'You weigh {wt} pounds!')

text:
For what I've got : if you want to import module a into module b without any specification of module a's path, module a and b must be in the same project.
Therefore you have probably done that by 'accident' by creating a new project.﻿

text:
Great tutorial! In the complete Django tutorial I would like to see topics discussed as:
- Security in general (SQL injections, CRSF, XSS etc)
- Access levels so users with different subscription have access to certain sections
- User registration
- Database integration (MySQL or Postgres)
- Google maps
- Form submission(Front end)
- Search for products (Front end)
- Autocomplete search (Front end)
- Image upload with manipulation(resizing, thumbnails etc) and security (verify that it is an actual image)
- Payments integrations
- API application
- Socket.io integration or similar
- DJango hosting on AWS using S3 buckets for storage

Any of the above topics would be super great along with the nice code style you provide and the suggestions. I might come back to edit my comment in order to update the topics. Thank you again for your quality courses.﻿

text:
Hi Sir, I have a question

       course="Python's for Beginners"
       print(course.title())

author: MING P

text:
The title method doesn't work very well when the string has apostrophes. To fix that issue, you could import the in-built module string and use one of  it's methods,  called capwords. 
Example:
#Code starts here:
import string


course = "python's for beginners"
print(string.capwords(course))


- - - -- - - - - - - -- - -- - - - - - -- - - -  --  - - - -
The output will be: 
Python's For Beginners﻿

I was having issues with it too. What I had to do what change prices from [10, 20, 30] to [10 + 20 + 30].


prices = [10 + 20 + 30]
total = 0

    print(f"Total: {total}")


There's what got it working for me.﻿

author: Magdalena Obrzut

text: Mosh used Excel's Format Cell option in the top toolbar to change the cell type from General/Number to Currency so that the $ appears and it's easier to see at a glance that we're working with prices. Excel doesn't like a mix of symbols/letters/numbers in a single cell and won't be able to perform any calculations unless it's just a number!﻿

kg_or_lbs = input("Your weight is in Kg or lbs: ")


if kg_or_lbs.lower() == "kg":
    lbs = converter.kg_to_lbs(weight)
    print(f"Your weight in libres is: {lbs} ")

elif kg_or_lbs.lower() == "lbs":
    kg = converter.lbs_to_kg(weight)
    print(f"Your weight in Kg is: {kg} ")﻿

text: Hi Mosh, i have started your course now, but i have doubt here , how the '*' which is string in quotes got multiplied with 10 = ********  and why the same multiplication not working while in the 'input'﻿
author: raju komakula

text: Good question. When you use that in the print function, you're writing an "expression". Python converts your expression to a value. In this case 10 stars. When you type that in the terminal window, Python takes it as the user input. It takes it exactly as it without interpreting it as Python code or an expression. That's exactly how it's supposed to work. Imagine you asked the question an answer, and they had to enter "10 * '*'". It wouldn't make sense for Python to convert that to 10 stars. Makes sense?﻿

text:
What would I like to do with Python? Tons of things. I would like to create my start-up or close to educational unit where children would learn real world programming since sper young age, so coding/programming would be there "native" tounge. I would add there plenty of emotional education, enterprenurial mindsets that teach them how to sustain motivation over the long term. SO they would be exiceted about how they can solve real world problems and help people around, improve pepole's lives, by codiing and automatization. Since I am big fan of both Elon Musk (SpaceX, Tesla) and DeepMind in the same time. I would like to merge missions of the two. Working title is "Einstein Crew" - which is self learning algorithms taught how to create in any area (Mars or other planets) completly on their own with tools they have - oxygen, food, shelter, energy. Instead of risking lives of people you send robots that provide running base with all the necceseary to survival for human beings conditions. Prepare as well landing zone, and signal emiters in order to let people land safaely and in controlled way. You send something like "lego blocks" with algorithms taught how to process resources or use "lego blocks" and they build all that is neccesary for human survival. As those are robots they can be sent even to Alpha Centauri to explore and start explore and prepare conditions for humans there as well. As those are robots, no need to worry about hibernation, exposure to radiation unless it hurts the TPU's and GPU's or any integral part of their architecture.
Other thing I would like to create is learning relation between signals (infra - red, video input, sound) for drones. Can algorithm learn just by randomly exploring the space and collecting sounds learn to understand human speech? So by no prior knowledge if human tells him "go left" and show him the direction with his hand(video-sound relation) dorne will fly left? Moreover - drone is rewarded for emiting sounds similiar to what he collects as inputs. Can he emulate human speech and use it for his communication? One dorne definietely would not be enough. Let's say it's 100 drones collecting the signals every day - then return the inputs for analysis to reinforcment neural nets. Algorithm is updated drones fly and collect once again. With that experiment there is another nice feature. 
Energy needed to fly the drone. Drone controls his energy level in his batteries, automatically goes to "charge mode" if he considers he will run low on eergy f.e. below 30%. Drones can as well be covered with solar panels (there are felxible solars based on crystals Peroskvites) he can look for places where the sun exposure is the strongest - therefore energy production and charging. SO he can become pretty much self sustainable in terms of energy.
Another thing - can you fully automatize energy production. From mining Silicon - producing silicon wafers, adding Borium and Phosporus, creating wiring and collecting final production. Fully automatized production including making orders for materials.
That's my python motivation.﻿

text:
Bed Mas is the order of operation:
Brackets, Exponents, Multiplication, Addition, Subtraction.
All computer programming, including in the real world, uses order of operation.
Example1: (2*4)+9-2= (8)+9-2= 8+7= 15
Example2: (2*4)+(9-2)= (8)+(7)= 8+7= 15
Example3: (2**4)*(9*2)= (16)*(18)= 16*18= 288﻿

# Reversing the data that we stored on a file. 

f = open("number","w")

f.write("1")
f.write("2")
f.write("3")
f.write("4")
f.write("5")

f = open("number","r")

for item in f:
    print(list(reversed(item)))
f.close()﻿

text: If i want to create web and desktop applications then what should i learn after python??﻿
author: Sameed khan

text:
HTML -> CSS -> JavaScript.
HTML is the markup of what lies on the page
CSS designs the layout or the page
JavaScript will make the page responsive.
Freecodecamp.org is a good place to start﻿
author: Operative Zero

text: For web applications, you need to learn Django (a Python framework) as well as HTML, CSS and SQL. That makes you a backend developer. If you want to get into full-stack development, you should also learn JavaScript. For desktop applications, there are various frameworks, PyQT and Kivy are the two most popular ones.﻿

I am a PhD student in the UK researching the use of a new magnetic sensor for detecting cracks and other flaws in structural materials like steel. I need to learn Python to help me build an image comparison tool (probably use OpenCV) to determine the repeatability of our scanning system by measuring how similar our magnetic field images are.

There are numerous image comparison tools out there but all of them are "black box" meaning that I would have very little understanding of how they work or how to optimise / change the parameters of them.﻿

credit = input("Buyer has good credit? Yes or No: ")
if credit == "Yes":

author: Stas

text: Boolean values are just True/False. We may set them explicitly in our program, or we may receive them from the user. For example, the user may fill out a form about a new loan applicant. One of the questions may be: "Does this person have a driver's license?" The user has to set it to Yes or No. This is where we use a boolean variable.﻿

text:
weigth = input("Tell us your weight: ")
conv = input("(L)bs or (K)g: ")

if conv == "k":
    pound = float(weigth) * 2.20   # 1 kg = 2.20libres
    pound = int(pound)
    print("You are " + str(pound) + " pounds")
else:
    kilos = float(weigth) * 0.45
    kilos = int(kilos)
    print("You are " + str(kilos) + " Kg")﻿

payment = price - int(down_payment)
print("Final Price with down payment is: " + str(payment) + "$")﻿

numbers = {
    0: "Zero",
    1: "One",
    2: "Two",
    3: "Three",
    4: "Four",
    5: "Five",
    6: "Six",
    7: "Seven",
    8: "Eight",
    9: "Nine"
}
Phone = reversed(input("Phone: ")) #because while looping it is being reversed
FinalString = ""
for number in Phone:
    FinalString = numbers[int(number)]+" "+FinalString
print(FinalString)


Can anybody tell me why I get a reversed input - I am having to reverse in manually to get the nuber in right order.﻿
author: DakshinSys

text:
I think the problem comes from the fact that you're adding FinalString after the new string from numbers. Try this:
FinalString = FinalString + " " + numbers[int(number)] 
OR
FinalString += " " + numbers[int(number)] 

Of course remove the reversed method﻿

author: Mohammad Aman

text:
I'd say learn Python well first. If you want to become a web developer, you need to MASTER Python. Make sure to complete this course, and do all the exercises. Then, I'd suggest you enroll in my Complete Python Course. That goes beyond this beginner's course and helps you master Python. After that, learn Django. I don't currently have a course on it but planning to create one soon. My or someone else's course, doesn't matter. Learn Django. On the side, you should also learn about HTML and CSS but they're pretty easy and you can pick them up in a few days or week. And one more thing: SQL! You need that to work with databases. Here's the order that I suggest: 


1- Python
2- Django 
3- SQL 
4- HTML / CSS﻿

author: Earl Bullock

text:
Hello Mosh,

I am in the Big Brother program and I have 2 - 13 year old boys who are not doing well in school.

But like all kids in middle school they are interested in computers.

So I decided to teach them Python as a way to get them interested in learning.

I am an engineer who has used many different programming packages but not Python, so I will also be learning.



I have watched a few of the Python Tutorial videos on youtube and liked yours the best.

You have a very easy way of explaining things and have organized the material very well.



My plan is to watch your tutorial with them and reinforce each subject with extra mini programs.

After we finish your tutorial I will be buying a raspberry PI robotics kit and program it using Python.



At the time of this post your video has been viewed 34,029 times.
Just think of all the people you have helped.

So a very big thank you for making this tutorial.﻿

text: I started trying to learn programming because I was interested in Arduino, but there are many challenges in Arduino and other toy robotics if you aren't already familiar with programming. I struggled until I started flying a cleanflight  drone with all of my free time, and then decided to start where the raspberry pi recommends, with basic python. Now that I have spent some time learning basic programming ideas, I sometimes think about jobs, but still mostly consider it a hobby pursuit. If I found an opportunity that I thought I could understand, however, I would be very excited to pursue that sort of occupation with my favorite,,, computers!﻿

text: @Programming with Mosh Ok, I just finished the openpyxl section. You asked what project I would like to work on, well, actually I have one that will probably amount to nothing more than my own practice, but is a real application. I understand that there are plenty of examples of great existing applications , but in my company (I am a warehouse laborer in a small company that distributes textiles, rolls of fabric,) , we are still tracking everything on paper, then some people in the office enter everything we hand-write into a program running on windows xp, that is actually not very full-featured. I want to be able to use my smartphone, and fill out a form that will then store the bin-move or bin-fill in such a way that I can immediately search for key-words to find the items or any other items, and also such the office can see ONLY those items that I moved. They don't use excel, but I could probably use excel  for android, (their database, I don't know what it is and it is a dos-looking program, but it's probably very easy to export to excel docs) , search excel to find items, and then have a small app that both creates a new doc for my daily moves, and also updates my full inventory doc, and I have a web-domain that I can use to host it for personal use. (because it's just for me to learn with!! ) ,,, anyway, I'm not ready, I don't know how to use SQL, which westhost has on my server, and I can barely use html, and don't know how to run python from the web-server...... but I have nothing but time!!! (they are using paper...... )﻿

text: There's a bug in your code. Your code only removes the first occurrence of a duplicate. For example, if you have three 5s, it'll only remove one of them! Plus, there's no need to sort after every remove.﻿
